etymology.description: 舌(舌) (shé, "tongue") with added horizontal stroke -> indicates movement of tongue for speech -> modern form adds another stroke on top
etymology.interpretation: The character 言(yán, "speech") visually emphasizes the movement of the tongue, illustrating how speech is produced through tongue actions. The additional stroke and evolution to a more abstract form highlight the facet of communication.

examples.chinese: 他的言令人信服(他的言令人信服)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de yán lìng rén xìn fú.

examples.chinese: 他喜欢研究古人的言论(他喜歡研究古人的言論)，并整理成册(並整理成冊)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xǐhuān yánjiū gǔ rén de yánlùn, bìng zhěnglǐ chéng cè.
examples.english: He likes to study the speeches of ancient people and compile them into volumes.
